@CopilotFallbackLC

Dear _____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that some of your messages were not delivered.

My recommendation is to add long code numbers into your application or to utilize Twilio's Copilot Service and enable the feature "Fallback to Long Code" so that if your end users numbers do not support short code, Twilio will fallback to using a long code numbers in your Msg Service number pool to send messages. Please note that this feature "Fallback to Long Code" only supports major carriers (T-Mobile, Sprint, Verizon, AT&T) and not minor carriers. Also, the "Fallback to Long Code" feature will only work if your end user's mobile plan does not support short code messaging. If it's due to other reasons, the "Fallback to Long Code" will not be initiated, hence it is still recommended that your application re-initiates API requests to Twilio to resend messages.


For more information please view below:


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/messaging-services-and-copilot-overview#fallback-to-lc


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.


Warmest Regards,
**Copilot - General Info for Fallback to Longcode

Dear _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am very sorry to hear that some of your messages were not delivered.
My recommendation is to add long code numbers into your application or to utilize Twilio's Copilot Service and enable the feature "Fallback to Long Code" so that if your end users numbers do not support short code, Twilio will fallback to using a long code numbers in your Msg Service number pool to send messages. Please note that this feature "Fallback to Long Code" only supports major carriers (T-Mobile, Sprint, Verizon, AT&T) and not minor carriers. Also, the "Fallback to Long Code" feature will only work if your end user's mobile plan does not support short code messaging. If it's due to other reasons, the "Fallback to Long Code" will not be initiated, hence it is still recommended that your application re-initiates API requests to Twilio to resend messages.
For more information please view below:
https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/messaging-services-and-copilot-overview#fallback-to-lc
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,
@CopilotSticky

OPTION 1:


Dear ____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am sorry to hear that you are experiencing issues with Sticky Sender.


Please note that by design, mappings are created after the first message is sent from your Messaging Service to a particular recipient. Any future messages sent to that recipient from that Messaging Service will also use the same From number. If you send inbound messages to your Twilio number first, Sticky Sender will not save that as a mapping, it has to be outbound from your Twilio number first for the mapping to be enabled.


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages-copilot#sticky-sender


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.


Warmest Regards,

--------


OPTION 2:


Dear _____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I hope today finds you well. Great question!


Yes, you are correct, the mapping is only created after the first message is sent **from** your Messaging Service to a particular recipient. Any future messages sent to that recipient from that Messaging Service will also use the same From number. The reason why the mapping is **not** created when an end user sends the first inbound text is because Twilio will not know which Messaging Service is being used. The first message needs to be sent from a Messaging Service to initiate Sticky Sender.


Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.


Warmest Regards,
**Copilot - General Info for Sticky Sender

OPTION 1:
Dear ____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I am sorry to hear that you are experiencing issues with Sticky Sender.
Please note that by design, mappings are created after the first message is sent from your Messaging Service to a particular recipient. Any future messages sent to that recipient from that Messaging Service will also use the same From number. If you send inbound messages to your Twilio number first, Sticky Sender will not save that as a mapping, it has to be outbound from your Twilio number first for the mapping to be enabled.
https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages-copilot#sticky-sender
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,

OPTION 2:
Dear _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. I hope today finds you well. Great question!
Yes, you are correct, the mapping is only created after the first message is sent **from** your Messaging Service to a particular recipient. Any future messages sent to that recipient from that Messaging Service will also use the same From number. The reason why the mapping is **not** created when an end user sends the first inbound text is because Twilio will not know which Messaging Service is being used. The first message needs to be sent from a Messaging Service to initiate Sticky Sender.
Please let me know if there is anything else I can help you with or further clarify. More than happy to help.
Warmest Regards,
@CopilotCountryGeomatch

Hello _____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!


Please note Country Code Geomatch is automatically turned on by default for Messaging Services.


The numbers in your Messaging Service Number Pool will automatically be used when sending messages to recipients within the same country code as the numbers within the Number Pool. When sending messages to recipients outside of the same country code, as long as the numbers in your Number Pool are internationally SMS capable, the numbers can also be used to send messages to international recipients.


Worthy to note, when a phone number of a new geographic country is added to your Messaging Service, Twilio will automatically select and remap any existing Sticky Sender mappings so that the From number can match the same country as your recipient's phone number.


To learn more about Country Code Geomatch, please see below:


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/messaging/services-and-copilot#country-code-geomatch


To learn more about what numbers Twilio offers and its capabilities, please see below:


https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223183068-Twilio-international-phone-number-availability-and-their-capabilities


Please let me know if you have further questions.


Thanks,
Copilot - General Info for Country Code Geomatch

Hello _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!
Please note Country Code Geomatch is automatically turned on by default for Messaging Services.
The numbers in your Messaging Service Number Pool will automatically be used when sending messages to recipients within the same country code as the numbers within the Number Pool. When sending messages to recipients outside of the same country code, as long as the numbers in your Number Pool are internationally SMS capable, the numbers can also be used to send messages to international recipients.
Worthy to note, when a phone number of a new geographic country is added to your Messaging Service, Twilio will automatically select and remap any existing Sticky Sender mappings so that the From number can match the same country as your recipient's phone number.
To learn more about Country Code Geomatch, please see below:
https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/messaging/services-and-copilot#country-code-geomatch
To learn more about what numbers Twilio offers and its capabilities, please see below:
https://support.twilio.com/hc/en-us/articles/223183068-Twilio-international-phone-number-availability-and-their-capabilities
Please let me know if you have further questions.
Thanks,
347E83FA-1BFC-4CBB-8932-A4752D3BBEBF
@CopilotAddNumbers

This is also correct, adding multiple numbers to your messaging services will definitely help balance and distribute your traffic so you do not go over message volume and sending rate limitations. I will advise to keep track of your daily volume and make sure you have enough numbers in your Messaging Services to balance out your traffic. The reason I say this is because as your traffic increases, Messaging Services will not automatically add numbers to your number pool. To ensure that you will not be carrier filtered and for Messaging Services to work most efficiently, please add additional numbers as your traffic increases.
Copilot - Messaging Services Will not Add Numbers Automatically

This is also correct, adding multiple numbers to your messaging services will definitely help balance and distribute your traffic so you do not go over message volume and sending rate limitations. I will advise to keep track of your daily volume and make sure you have enough numbers in your Messaging Services to balance out your traffic. The reason I say this is because as your traffic increases, Messaging Services will not automatically add numbers to your number pool. To ensure that you will not be carrier filtered and for Messaging Services to work most efficiently, please add additional numbers as your traffic increases.
@CopilotResponseTimes

Copilot response time is ~100 ms and non-copilot is 250 ms. So for each concurrency “slot” you can do 10 copilot requests per second instead of 1. So 100 concurrent API requests is like 800-1000 requests per second if you use Copilot.


rather than retrying they should be rate limiting how many open requests they have at a time.

from the user-agent in the API logs it looks like they’re using node (https://reports-looker.corp.twilio.com/x/BPpjjnh)

you could recommend this library: http://caolan.github.io/async/

we don’t have per second or per minute API limits, it’s all about how many are open concurrently, so there’s no guidance around how long to wait to retry.
**Copilot - General Info on Response Times and Concurrent Request

Copilot response time is ~100 ms and non-copilot is 250 ms. So for each concurrency “slot” you can do 10 copilot requests per second instead of 1. So 100 concurrent API requests is like 800-1000 requests per second if you use Copilot.
rather than retrying they should be rate limiting how many open requests they have at a time. from the user-agent in the API logs it looks like they’re using node (https://reports-looker.corp.twilio.com/x/BPpjjnh) you could recommend this library: http://caolan.github.io/async/ we don’t have per second or per minute API limits, it’s all about how many are open concurrently, so there’s no guidance around how long to wait to retry.
F34EFC6F-F9C7-4D4D-95B0-EDAD290BCE55
@CopilotShortcode

Dear _____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!


I believe you are referring to Messaging Services' Short Code Reroute feature that I have attached more information below:


https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages-copilot#shortcode-reroute


When your Messaging Service includes a shortcode, Twilio will always prioritize message delivery with the short code. If a carrier is not supported by a Twilio short code, Twilio will automatically deliver the message with a long code in your Messaging Service. Please note that Twilio will not be able to detect whether individual users enabled the short code functionality on their mobile plan or not. Twilio will **only** reroute to using long code if we do not support short code message for minor carriers. Since Sprint is supported as a major carrier, this feature will not be applicable for major carriers.


https://www.twilio.com/help/faq/short-codes/what-carriers-are-supported-on-twilio-short-codes


I will close this ticket for now, please feel free to respond to reopen this ticket if you have further questions. Have a great day.


Warmest Regards,
**Copilot - General Information for Short Code Reroute

Dear _____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!
I believe you are referring to Messaging Services' Short Code Reroute feature that I have attached more information below:
https://www.twilio.com/docs/api/rest/sending-messages-copilot#shortcode-reroute
When your Messaging Service includes a shortcode, Twilio will always prioritize message delivery with the short code. If a carrier is not supported by a Twilio short code, Twilio will automatically deliver the message with a long code in your Messaging Service. Please note that Twilio will not be able to detect whether individual users enabled the short code functionality on their mobile plan or not. Twilio will **only** reroute to using long code if we do not support short code message for minor carriers. Since Sprint is supported as a major carrier, this feature will not be applicable for major carriers.
https://www.twilio.com/help/faq/short-codes/what-carriers-are-supported-on-twilio-short-codes
I will close this ticket for now, please feel free to respond to reopen this ticket if you have further questions. Have a great day.
Warmest Regards,
@CopilotTestNumbers

Hello ____,


Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!


Please note that test credentials and the magic number +15005550006 is not currently supported for Messaging Services. However, I understand that you are trying to scale, we highly recommend adding Twilio numbers to your Messaging Service and just using the Messaging Service SID. This allows Twilio to quickly distribute your traffic across the phone numbers in your Messaging Service.

Please let me know if you have further questions.


Thanks,
Copilot - Does not Support Magic Numbers and Test Credentials

Hello ____,
Thank you for contacting Twilio Support. Great question!
Please note that test credentials and the magic number +15005550006 is not currently supported for Messaging Services. However, I understand that you are trying to scale, we highly recommend adding Twilio numbers to your Messaging Service and just using the Messaging Service SID. This allows Twilio to quickly distribute your traffic across the phone numbers in your Messaging Service.
Please let me know if you have further questions.
Thanks,
AAE20A22-28EE-49D3-B6DB-3DD95FD98EBF
